required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Ultrasound-guided Thoracic Spinal Level Identification Using Rhomboid Muscle as a Reference Landmark

brief_summary.textblock: Typically, the rhomboid minor muscles rise from the C7-T1 spinous process and run downward to touch the upper inner corner of the scapula, and the rhomboid major muscles rise from the T2-T5 spinous process and run downward to reach the lower middle inner corner of the scapula. In anatomical research articles, it has been reported that the rhomboid muscle's anatomical variations are rare. Considering the characteristics of these rhomboid muscles, the investigators planned a study on the utility of rhomboid muscles as a landmark for identifying thoracic spine levels.

primary_outcome.description: Thoracic vertebra level of radiopaque marker labeled on the rhomboid muscle inferior margin on C-arm

secondary_outcome.measure: 1. Changes in marker position when raised the arm above the head and in a relaxed position

secondary_outcome.description: The presence of rhomboid muscle fusion

secondary_outcome.measure: 3. Visibility grade of muscle fascia using Ultrasound (I - IV)
secondary_outcome.description: A. Grade I: Definitely visible B. Grade II: Somewhat visible C. Grade III: Barely visible D. Grade IV: Not visible

secondary_outcome.measure: 4. Depth: The distance from the skin where the marker is attached to the transverse process of thoracic spine
5. Difference between left and right sides
secondary_outcome.description: The distance between left and right inferior thoracic spine attachment site of rhomboid muscle

arm_group.description: Ultrasound scanning of the rhomboid muscle

intervention.description: The researchers use ultrasound to scan the left and right sides of the paravertebral sagittal imaging to identify trapezius, semispinalis, erector spinae muscle, transverse process and rhomboid muscle. The radiopaque marker is attached respectively to the skin of the inferior margin of the rhomboid muscle on the left and right thoracic spinal spines. Then, as the first step for the scheduled nerve block to the patient, thoracic vertebra level verification using C-arm is performed. At this time, left and right level of the transverse process of thoracic spine marked with the radiopaque marker are confirmed and recorded.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing thoracic nerve root block due to herpes zoster, postherpetic neuralgia, complex regional pain syndrome, post traumatic pain syndrome, or compression fracture of vertebra.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Previous T-spine surgery
2. Patient refusal
3. Coagulopathy
4. Generalized infection or localized infection at injection site
5. Anatomical abnormality of T-spine
6. Allergic reaction to local anesthetics
